items.title: DbApi is not PEP 249 compliant
items.body:
https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0249/#description

description should be allowed after execute. https://github.com/prestodb/presto-python-client/blob/master/prestodb/dbapi.py#L195
In the code, the description will not work unless a fetch is called.

Dropbox did this https://github.com/dropbox/PyHive/blob/master/pyhive/presto.py#L224 to support description after execute as required by PEP249

items.title: Got PERMISSION_DENIED USER_ERROR while executing query
items.body:
Hey guys, I'm new to Presto and I'm trying to play around with it using presto-python-client. I successfully built the connection but when I run some basic `SELECT` queries like `SELECT COUNT(*) from <table_name>` I got following Error: `PrestoUserError(type=USER_ERROR, name=PERMISSION_DENIED, message="Access Denied: Cannot select from table <schema_name.table_name> ", query_id=*******)`. I already executed `cur.execute("set role admin")` before executing any query and it returned `true` to me.  

Anyone can help me with this problem?

items.title: How to provide certificate file when connecting to presto
items.body:
I am having this error:
(Caused by SSLError(SSLError("bad handshake: Error([('SSL routines', 'tls_process_server_certificate', 'certificate verify failed')])")))

when trying to connect to presto using the prestodb client
```
import prestodb

conn=prestodb.dbapi.connect(
    host='host.name',
    user='myuser',
    catalog='catalog',
    schema='schema',
    port='443',
    http_scheme='https'
)
cur = conn.cursor()
cur.execute('SELECT * FROM table limit 10')
rows = cur.fetchall()
```
In sqlalchamey I was able to make it work using this code:
```
engine_presto = create_engine(
    'presto://host.name:443',
    connect_args={
        'protocol': 'https',
        'requests_kwargs': {'verify': '/pat/to/cert.pem'}
    }
)

sql_str = 'SELECT * from table limit 10'
df = pd.read_sql(sql_str, con=engine_presto)
```
How can I provide my cert.pem file to the prestodb client

items.title: Best way to ignore SSL verification?
items.body:
I want to ignore SSL verification but not sure exactly how to do that. The complaint comes at `cur.execute(query)` and the error returned is

`urllib3.exceptions.MaxRetryError: HTTPSConnectionPool(host='presto-dev.interactivedatastore.viasat.io', port=443): Max retries exceeded with url: /v1/statement (Caused by SSLError(SSLError(1, '[SSL: CERTIFICATE_VERIFY_FAILED] certificate verify failed (_ssl.c:777)'),))`

I know that that adding verify=False in the requests API generally resolves this issue but not sure how to incorporate that here.

items.title: Make dependency to request_kerberos optional
items.body: [`prestodb.auth`](https://github.com/prestodb/presto-python-client/blob/master/prestodb/auth.py) module provides a concrete class to setup Kerberos authentication. It requires the dependency *requests_kerberos* that eventually depends on a native library. This native library introduces complexity to build presto-python-client whereas most people don't need it. The purpose of this issue is to relax the requirement on *request_kerberos* while providing an easy to request it.

I have the same environment that some peers have and I'm the only one encountering the issue.  Any suggestions as to what may be causing this? I'm on OS X 10.13.3 and can provide the conda environment I'm using if need be.

items.title: Transaction commit fails with ABANDONED error
items.body: We saw data pipelines where the transaction was reported as successfully but the Presto query logs show that the `COMMIT` statement failed with an `ABANDONED_QUERY` error.

items.title: Handle unicode properly with urlunparse
items.body:
Stacktrace in production:
```
...
  File "/data/users/jamessun/fbsource/fbcode/buck-out/dev/gen/dataswarm/main#link-tree/prestodb/dbapi.py", line 188, in execute
    result = self._query.execute()
  File "/data/users/jamessun/fbsource/fbcode/buck-out/dev/gen/dataswarm/main#link-tree/prestodb/client.py", line 479, in execute
    response = self._request.post(self._sql)
  File "/data/users/jamessun/fbsource/fbcode/buck-out/dev/gen/dataswarm/main#link-tree/prestodb/client.py", line 311, in post
    self.statement_url,
  File "/data/users/jamessun/fbsource/fbcode/buck-out/dev/gen/dataswarm/main#link-tree/prestodb/client.py", line 299, in statement_url
    return self.get_url(constants.URL_STATEMENT_PATH)
  File "/data/users/jamessun/fbsource/fbcode/buck-out/dev/gen/dataswarm/main#link-tree/prestodb/client.py", line 294, in get_url
    return urlunparse((self._http_scheme, destination, path, '', '', ''))
  File "/data/users/jamessun/fbsource/fbcode/buck-out/dev/gen/dataswarm/main#link-tree/future/backports/urllib/parse.py", line 387, in urlunparse
    _coerce_args(*components))
  File "/data/users/jamessun/fbsource/fbcode/buck-out/dev/gen/dataswarm/main#link-tree/future/backports/urllib/parse.py", line 115, in _coerce_args
    raise TypeError("Cannot mix str and non-str arguments")
TypeError: Cannot mix str and non-str arguments
```

The error won't occur if the following import is removed:
`from __future__ import unicode_literals`

Similar issue:
https://github.com/jfinkels/flask-restless/issues/594
https://github.com/rst2pdf/rst2pdf/issues/596

items.title: Handle redirects with kerberos
items.body: Looks like the problem (https://github.com/requests/requests-kerberos/issues/64) is not going to be resolved anytime soon. As discuss, we need to provide the client a customized way to handle redirects

items.title: Retry fails with 503
items.body: Retry currently lives at http.`post`/`get`/`delete` level. 503 error is handled in `process()`. Raising a 503 error in `process()` is not going to invoke retry. This could also be a problem with authentication retry. Need to think about how to abstract retry in a more generic way.

items.title: Add interface to set custom HTTP headers
items.body: `dbapi.Cursor` should provide an interface to set custom HTTP headers in Presto queries.

items.title: Add interface to set connection and read timeout
items.body:
Some environment are more exposed to network congestion or JVM stalls, for example from full GC. However it costs more when the client abandons the query and submits it again, than to have longer timeouts at the socket level. Batch computations are usually less latency sensitive and more tolerant to higher timeouts.

`requests`allows to set the sockets connection and read timeouts. The `dbapi.Cursor` object should provide an interface to set them.

items.body: When I create the same table twice, no error get thrown at all ...

items.title: Expose query status from cursor
items.body: Would be awesome if we can get the query status from cursor, like the nextUri

items.title: Add support for transactions
items.body:
Presto provides 3 SQL statements to control transactions:
- [`START TRANSACTION`](https://prestodb.io/docs/current/sql/start-transaction.html)
- [`COMMIT`](https://prestodb.io/docs/current/sql/commit.html)
- [`ROLLBACK`](https://prestodb.io/docs/current/sql/rollback.html)

The *client* begins a transaction by sending a `START TRANSACTION` statement with a `X-Transaction-Id=NONE` header to the *coordinator*. The *coordinator* will then set the value of `X-Transaction-Id` to the actual transaction ID to use.

The *client* uses this transaction ID for subsequent SQL statement it executes, until it either `COMMIT` or `ROLLBACK` the transaction.

Some connectors does not support transactions. 
Each connector implements transactions with multiple isolation levels:

- `READ UNCOMMITTED`
- `READ COMMITTED`
- `REPEATABLE`
- `READ SERIALIZABLE`

[DBAPI 2.0 begins a transaction](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0249/#commit) for every query and assumes the database does not auto-commit i.e. the transaction has to commit to execute the SQL statements within it.

Example:

```python
db = prestodb.dbapi.connect(HOSTNAME, PORT, USER)
cursor = db.cursor()
try:
    cur.execute ("UPDATE versions SET status='stable' where version='2.6.0'")
    cur.execute ("UPDATE versions SET status='old' where version='2.4.4'")
    db.commit()
except Exception:
    db.rollback()
```

In [DBAPI 2.0](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0249/), a transaction is started for each call to `Connection.cursor()`. At this moment, the *client* sends a `START TRANSACTION` to the *coordinator* and gets the transaction ID in response. It then uses this transaction ID for all subsequent calls to `Cursor.execute()` until the transaction commits or rollbacks by  respectively sending `COMMIT or `ROLLBACK` to the coordinator. The commit is done by an the instance of `Connection`.
